definitions.definition: a curved piece of metal, plastic or wire for hanging things on, catching fish with, etc.

examples.text: The key was hanging from a hook.
Your coat’s hanging on a hook behind the door.

definitions.definition: a short hard hit that is made with the elbow bent

examples.text: a left hook to the jaw

definitions.definition: a way of hitting the ball so that it curves to the side instead of going straight ahead (usually by mistake in golf, but deliberately in cricket)
a thing that is used to make people interested in something

examples.text: The images are used as a hook to get children interested in science.
Well-chosen quotations can serve as a hook to catch the reader’s interest.

definitions.definition: using any method you can, even a dishonest one

examples.text: What I said was not true, but he fell for it *(= believed it)* hook, line and sinker.

definitions.definition: having got free from a difficult situation or a punishment

examples.text: I lied to get him off the hook.
No way will she let you off the hook this time.
I was finally off the hook.

definitions.definition: if you leave or take a landline phone off the hook, you take the receiver (= the part that you pick up) off the place where it usually rests, so that nobody can call you

examples.text: Citizens are increasingly on the hook for more of their own medical costs.

definitions.definition: to ring many times, with one phone call after another

examples.text: The phone has been ringing off the hook with offers of help.

wordOrigin: Old English hōc, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch hoek ‘corner, angle, projecting piece of land’, also to German Haken ‘hook’.
